result.markdown:
--- title: "The City of Engagement: Undestanding the Demographics and Financial Characteristics of its Residents" subtitle: "Based on a survey of 1,011 representative residents" author: "KB" date: last-modified editor: visual execute: freeze: auto warning: false format: html: code-fold: true code-summary: "Show the code" code-line-numbers: true toc-depth: 4 --- ![Photo: Hadi Zaher](images/paste-B4B7171E.png "City of Griffith, Australia"){fig-alt="Photo from https://www.domain.com.au/news/griffith-the-charming-town-showing-its-cultural-and-culinary-diversity-with-an-agricultural-backdrop-1045676/" fig-align="center"} (First Published: 14-May-2023) 1. Overview 1.1 Setting the Scene City of Engagement, with a total population of 50,000, is a small city located at Country of Nowhere. The city serves as a service centre of an agriculture region surrounding the city. The main agriculture of the region is fruit farms and vineyards. The city council is in the process of preparing the Local Plan 2023. A sample survey of representative residents had been conducted to collect data related to their household demographic and spending patterns, among other things. The city aims to use the data to assist with their major community revitalization efforts, including how to allocate a very large city renewal grant they have recently received. 1.2 Our Task We are required to create a user-friendly and interactive solution to help city managers and planners to explore the complex data in an engaging way and reveal hidden patterns. To this end, we will apply the concepts and methods learned from Lesson 1-4 of the course to reveal the **demographic** and **financial characteristics** of the city, using appropriate static and interactive statistical graphics methods. 2. Set Up 2.1 Load the relevant packages into the R environment We use the `pacman::p_load()` function to load the required R packages into our working environment. The loaded packages are: - **plotly**: For creating interactive web-based graphs. - **ggstatsplot**: For creating graphics with details from statistical tests. - **knitr**: For dynamic report generation - **kableExtra**: For additional functionality to format `kable()` tables created using **Knitr** - **pacthwork**: For combining plots\*\* - **ggdist**: For visualising distribution and uncertainty - **ggthemes**: Provides additional themes for **ggplot2** - **gridExtra**: For combining multiple plots into a single plot - **tidyverse**: A collection of core packages designed for data science, used extensively for data preparation and wrangling. - **DT**: For creating interactive tables using the DataTables JavaScript library - **reshape2**: For transforming dataframes from one shape to another - **calheatmapR**: For generating calendar heatmaps ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} #Load packages pacman::p_load(plotly, ggstatsplot, knitr, kableExtra, patchwork, ggdist, gridExtra,ggthemes, tidyverse, DT, reshape2, calheatmapR) ``` ::: 2.2 Import the data-sets Two data-sets are provided for this exercise: \(i\) Partcipants.csv: contains information about the 1011 city residents who responded to the survey. Other than an identifier variable, we also have the household size, a boolean indicator for households having children, age, education level, interest group and joviality (or happiness) level of the respondents. We import the records in the Participants.csv file as *survey*, convert the `participantId`, `householdSize` and `age` from numeric to integer data type, and convert `educationLevel` from character data type to an ordinal factor. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Import Participant.csv and assign it to survey variable survey <- read_csv('data/Participants.csv', show_col_types = FALSE ) %>% mutate(participantId = as.integer(participantId), householdSize = as.integer(householdSize), age = as.integer(age), educationLevel = as.factor(educationLevel) ) %>% mutate(educationLevel = ordered(educationLevel, levels = c("Low","HighSchoolOrCollege", "Bachelors","Graduate"))) ``` ::: \(ii\) FinancialJournal.csv contains the financial transactions of the respondents from 1 Mar 2022 to 28 Feb 2023. Other than an identifier variable (which permits us to cross-reference to the participants' demographic information), the time, nature and amount invol/ved for the transactions were also provided. Similarly, we import the records in the FinancialJournal.csv file as *financials*, and convert the `participantID` from numeric to integer data type and round the `amount` values to 2 decimal point. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Import FinancialJournal.csv and assign it to financials variable financials <- read_csv('data/FinancialJournal.csv', show_col_types = FALSE) %>% mutate(participantId = as.integer(participantId), amount = round(amount,2) ) ``` ::: 3. Data Wrangling 3.1 Create a month_year column for temporal analysis There are 1.5 million financial transactions over the 12-month period and the daily information is too granular for us to analyse. We will create a `month_year` column, from the `timestamp` column, which will then allow us to aggregate the transactions by month for temporal analysis. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Insert a month_year column financials <- financials %>% mutate(month_year = format(timestamp, "%b-%Y")) %>% mutate(month_year = as.factor(month_year)) %>% mutate(month_year = ordered(month_year, levels = c("Mar-2022", "Apr-2022","May-2022","Jun-2022","Jul-2022","Aug-2022","Sep-2022","Oct-2022","Nov-2022", "Dec-2022","Jan-2023","Feb-2023"))) ``` ::: 3.2 Recode Rental Adjustments as part of Shelter Expense Rent Adjustments do not occur frequently (only 131 transactions out of the 1.5 million financial transactions relate to `RentAdjustment` ) and they are essentially price adjustments associated with the cost of accommodation or rental refunds to the respondents. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Group and sumarise the transactions by category financials_grouped <- financials %>% group_by(category) %>% summarise(Count = n(), Sum_of_Amt = round(sum(amount),2)) # Display the results in tabular format and highliht RentalAdjustment transactions datatable(financials_grouped, options = list(dom='t'), caption = "Table 1: Breakdown of Financial Journal Transactions By Categories", rownames = FALSE) %>% formatStyle(1, target = 'row', backgroundColor = styleEqual(c('RentAdjustment'), c('#c7e9c0'))) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: As such, Rent Adjustment transactions are recoded as Shelter in the financials table. After the recoding, the new breakdown of transactions by category is as follows: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Make a copy of the financials table financials_recoded <- financials # Recode all 'RentAdjustment' transactions to 'Shelter' financials_recoded$category <- ifelse(financials_recoded$category =='RentAdjustment','Shelter', financials_recoded$category) # Group and sumarise the transactions by category after recoding financials_grouped <- financials_recoded %>% group_by(category) %>% summarise(Count = n(), Sum_of_Amt = round(sum(amount),2)) # Display the results in tabular format and highliht Shelter transactions datatable(financials_grouped, options = list(dom='t'), caption = "Table 2: New breakdown of Financial Journal Transactions By Categories (after recoding)", rownames = FALSE) %>% formatStyle(1, target = 'row', backgroundColor = styleEqual(c('Shelter'), c('#c7e9c0'))) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: 3.3 Remove duplicate records found in the financial data We notice duplicate records in the financial data. For instance, a survey participant (with Id=0) has duplicate records for Education and Shelter for the same amount and timestamp. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} participant_0 <- financials_recoded[,-5] %>% filter(participantId=='0') %>% group_by_all() %>% filter(n()>1) %>% arrange_all() datatable(participant_0, options = list(dom='t'), caption = "Table 3: Original and Duplicate Financial Records of a Survey Participant (Id=0)", rownames = FALSE) %>% formatStyle(3, target = 'row', backgroundColor = styleEqual(c('Education'), c('#efedf5'))) %>% formatStyle(3, target = 'row', backgroundColor = styleEqual(c('Shelter'), c('#9e9ac8'))) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: Applying the `duplicated()` function on the financial data, we have: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} paste(sum(duplicated(financials_recoded)),"duplicate records.") ``` ::: We are unsure of the reasons behind the duplicate records ðŸ˜•. Nonetheless, we will use the `distinct()` function on the financial data to only retain unique records for our analysis. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} financials_unique <- financials_recoded %>% distinct() ``` ::: 3.4 Summarise the financial information by participants We aggregate the financial information by participants, taking into consideration the timestamp and category using the `dcast()` function from **reshape2** package. After performing the following steps, we notice 131 survey participants only had transaction records for Mar-2022 , but not in the other months : - Group the transactions by participantId, pivot the information by month_year and count the number of transactions per month - Add a new column, "Months_with_trans", which sum up the no. of months over the 12-month period where there were transactions - Perform a value count of the "Months_with_trans" column and this reveals the number of participants who only had 1 month of financial transactions. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Group the transactions by participantId, pivot the information by month_year and count the number of transactions per month. financials_count <- dcast(financials_unique, participantId ~ month_year, value.var = "amount", fun.aggregate = length) # Add a new column, "Months_with_trans", which sum up the no. of months over the 12-month period where there were transactions. financials_count$Months_with_trans <- apply(financials_count[,2:13]!=0,1,sum) # Perform a value count of the "Months_with_trans" column summary_count <- financials_count %>% group_by(Months_with_trans)%>% summarise(Count=n()) datatable(summary_count, options = list(dom='t'), caption = "Table 4: No. of Survey Participants grouped by the count of months with transactions", rownames = FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: The reason for the economic activity of the 131 participants appearing only in Mar-2022 is unclear and requires further investigation. To avoid biasing our results which covers the entire year, we will remove the records of these 131 participants from our subsequent analysis. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # List those participants who only had transaction records for 1 month and assign it id_to_exclude ids_to_exclude <- c(financials_count[financials_count$Months_with_trans==1,]$participantId) # Exclude from the financial_unique data-set participants whose id are in id_to_exclude list financials_880 <- subset(financials_unique, !(participantId %in% ids_to_exclude)) ``` ::: Next. we derive the the monthly and total wages of the 880 participants. The first 5 records of the wage information are as follow: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} wages_880 <- dcast(subset(financials_880,(category == 'Wage')), participantId ~ month_year, value.var = "amount", sum) %>% mutate(total_wages = rowSums(.[2:13],na.rm=TRUE)) # Inspect the first 5 records datatable(head(wages_880, n=5), options = list(dom='t'), caption = "Table 5: First 5 records of the Monthly and Total Wages", rownames = FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: Based on Table 2 above, Education, Shelter, Food and Entertainment are all living expenses and we will also work out the monthly living expenses and the year's total for the 880 participants. The first 5 records of the expenses information are as follow: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} expenses_880 <- dcast(subset(financials_880,!(category == 'Wage')), participantId ~ month_year, value.var = "amount", sum) %>% mutate(total_expenses = rowSums(.[2:13],na.rm=TRUE)) # Inspect the first 5 records datatable(head(expenses_880, n=5), options = list(dom='t'), caption = "Table 6: First 5 records of the Monthly and Total Expenses", rownames = FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: 3.5 Combine the Participants' Demographic and Financial Data We combine both sets of information into a single table and include 3 new columns: - total_surplus : refers to the amount of wage surplus (or deficit) based on the difference between total wage and total expenses for the year. - expense_to_wage: the proportion of total expenses over total wages - surplus_to_wage: the proportion of total surplus over total wages for our subsequent analysis. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} merged <- survey %>% inner_join(select(wages_880, participantId, total_wages), by = "participantId") %>% inner_join(select(expenses_880, participantId, total_expenses), by = "participantId") %>% mutate(total_surplus = total_wages + total_expenses, expense_to_wage = round(abs(total_expenses/total_wages),3), surplus_to_wage = round(total_surplus/total_wages,3) ) datatable(head(merged, n=5), options = list(dom='t'), caption = "Table 7: First 5 records of the Merged Demgraphic and Financial Data Table", rownames = FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: 4. The Demographics of the 880 Participants First we will prepare a few plots to get a preliminary understanding of the profile of the 880 participants. Education Level ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} colors <- c('rgb(211,94,96)', 'rgb(128,133,133)', 'rgb(144,103,167)', 'rgb(171,104,87)') education <- merged %>% subset(select = c(participantId, educationLevel)) %>% group_by(educationLevel) %>% summarise(count = n()) %>% plot_ly(labels = ~educationLevel, values = ~count, textposition = 'middle center', textinfo = 'label+percent', insidetextorientation='radial', insidetextfont = list(color = '#FFFFFF', textangle = 0), hoverinfo = 'text', text = ~paste(count, ' participants'), marker = list(colors = colors, line = list(color = '#FFFFFF', width = 1))) %>% add_pie(hole=0.6) %>% layout(title = list(text = '48% of Participants have High School or College Education', font = list(size = 15)), xaxis = list(showgrid = FALSE, zeroline = FALSE, showticklabels = FALSE), yaxis = list(showgrid = FALSE, zeroline = FALSE, showticklabels = FALSE), showlegend = FALSE) subplot(education) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: Household szie ::: {.cell fig.size='14'} ```{.r .cell-code} colors <- c('rgb(211,94,96)', 'rgb(128,133,133)', 'rgb(144,103,167)', 'rgb(171,104,87)') hh_size <- merged %>% subset(select = c(participantId, householdSize)) %>% group_by(householdSize) %>% summarise(count = n()) %>% plot_ly(labels = ~householdSize, values = ~count, textposition = 'middle center', textinfo = paste('label+percent'), insidetextfont = list(color = '#FFFFFF', textangle = 0), hoverinfo = 'text', text = ~paste(count, ' participants'), marker = list(colors = colors, line = list(color = '#FFFFFF', width = 1))) %>% add_pie(hole=0.6) %>% layout(title = list(text = 'Household Size', font = list(size = 15)), xaxis = list(showgrid = FALSE, zeroline = FALSE, showticklabels = FALSE), yaxis = list(showgrid = FALSE, zeroline = FALSE, showticklabels = FALSE), showlegend = FALSE) have_kids <- merged %>% subset(select = c(participantId, haveKids)) %>% group_by(haveKids) %>% summarise(count = n()) %>% plot_ly(labels = ~haveKids, values = ~count, textposition = 'top center', textinfo = 'label+percent', insidetextfont = list(color = '#FFFFFF', textangle = 0), hoverinfo = 'text', text = ~paste(count, ' participants'), marker = list(colors = colors, line = list(color = '#FFFFFF', width = 1))) %>% add_pie(hole=0.6) %>% layout(title = list(text = 'haveKids', font = list(size = 15)), xaxis = list(showgrid = FALSE, zeroline = FALSE, showticklabels = FALSE), yaxis = list(showgrid = FALSE, zeroline = FALSE, showticklabels = FALSE), showlegend = FALSE) subplot(hh_size, have_kids, widths = c(0.5, 0.5)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: havekids ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} colors <- c('rgb(211,94,96)', 'rgb(128,133,133)', 'rgb(144,103,167)', 'rgb(171,104,87)') have_kids <- merged %>% subset(select = c(participantId, haveKids)) %>% group_by(haveKids) %>% summarise(count = n()) %>% plot_ly(labels = ~haveKids, values = ~count, textposition = 'top center', textinfo = 'label+percent', insidetextfont = list(color = '#FFFFFF', textangle = 0), hoverinfo = 'text', text = ~paste(count, ' participants'), marker = list(colors = colors, line = list(color = '#FFFFFF', width = 1))) %>% add_pie(hole=0.6) %>% layout(title = list(text = 'haveKids', font = list(size = 15)), xaxis = list(showgrid = FALSE, zeroline = FALSE, showticklabels = FALSE), yaxis = list(showgrid = FALSE, zeroline = FALSE, showticklabels = FALSE), showlegend = FALSE) subplot(have_kids, hh_size, nrows = 1) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: Age Distribution ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} age_dist <- ggplot(data=merged, aes(x= age)) + geom_histogram(binwidth = 5, color="black", fill='lightgray', linewidth = 0.1) + xlim(c(15, 60)) + ylim(c(0,150)) + geom_vline(aes(xintercept=mean(age)), color="red", linetype="dashed", size=1) + geom_vline(aes(xintercept=median(age)), color="grey30", linetype="dashed", size=1) + xlab('Age') + ylab('Count') + ggtitle("The Median and Mean Age of the Participants is 39") + theme_minimal() ggplotly(age_dist) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: The relatively flat distribution for the age histogram above indicates slow population growth in the city, with the residents just reproducing enough to replace itself. Income heatmap ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} income_cal_hm <- financials_880 %>% filter(category=='Wage') %>% subset(select = c(participantId,timestamp,amount)) %>% mutate(date = as.Date(format(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d")))%>% group_by(date) %>% summarise(count = n(), avg_amt = mean(amount)) %>% subset(select=c(date,avg_amt)) # Create a named list which will server my_list_wage <- setNames(with(income_cal_hm, as.list(round(avg_amt,2))), as.numeric(as.POSIXct(income_cal_hm$date))) ``` ::: We will next plot a calendar heatmap: ::: {.cell .caption-top fig.asp='0.618'} ```{.r .cell-code} calheatmapR(data = my_list_wage, height = "200%", width = "100%") %>% chDomain(domain = "month", subDomain = "day", start = "2022-03-01", range=12, cellSize = 12, dynamicDimension = TRUE) %>% chLegend(legend = seq(0, 1000, 100), colours = list(min = "#f7fcf5", max = "#00441b", empty = "#424242"), cellSize = 15, cellPadding = 5, ) %>% chLabel(itemName = 'dollars of average wage per participant') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` Happy Like a fish ::: ::: Expenditure heatmap 4.1For Total Expenses Data Preparation ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} expense_cal_hm <- financials_880 %>% filter(category != "Wage") %>% subset(select = c(participantId,category, timestamp,amount)) %>% mutate(date = as.Date(format(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d")))%>% group_by(date) %>% summarise(count = n(), avg_amt = mean(amount)) %>% subset(select=c(date,avg_amt)) # Create a named list which will server my_list_expenses <- setNames(with(expense_cal_hm, as.list(round(abs(avg_amt),2))), as.numeric(as.POSIXct(expense_cal_hm$date))) ``` ::: Plot the map ::: {.cell .fig-cap-location-top fig.asp='0.618'} ```{.r .cell-code} calheatmapR(data = my_list_expenses, height = "200%", width = "100%") %>% chDomain(domain = "month", subDomain = "day", start = "2022-03-01", range=12, cellSize = 12, dynamicDimension = TRUE) %>% chLegend(legend = seq(0, 200, 20), colours = list(min = "#fcfbfd", max = "#3f007d", empty = "#424242"), cellSize = 15, cellPadding = 5, ) %>% chLabel(itemName = 'dollars of average expenditure') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` Particpants spend less $50 on average per day ::: ::: 4. The Joviality and Financial Health of the Participants 5.1 Whether a higher education qualification results in more income First, we develop a function will us to visualise the normality of the data using a Quantile-Quantile Plot and we want to conduct a Shapiro-Wilk Test for Normality to confirm that the data points follow a Normal distribution. For the Shapiro-Wilk Test, we hypothesize H0 = The distribution of data is Normal, at 0.05 level of significance. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} norm_test_wages <- function(df, column) { category <- if (is.factor(df[[column]])) { levels(df[[column]]) } else if (is.character(df[[column]])) { sort(unique(df[[column]])) } else { sort(unique(as.character(df[[column]]))) } plots <- list() for (class in category) { subset_df <- filter(df, !!sym(column) == class) shapiro_res <- shapiro.test(subset_df$total_wages) p_value <- format(shapiro_res$p.value, digits = 3) is_normal <- ifelse(shapiro_res$p.value > 0.05, "Yes", "No") g <- ggplot(subset_df, aes(sample = total_wages)) + stat_qq() + stat_qq_line() + ggtitle(paste('QQ Plot for', class)) + xlab(paste(column,':',class)) + ylab("Total Wages") + theme_minimal() + annotate("label", x = -0.5, y = Inf, hjust = 1, vjust = 1.5, label = paste("Shapiro-Wilk Normality Test:", "\n", "p-value = ", p_value, "\n", "Is normal distn? ", is_normal), fill = "white" ) plots[[class]] <- g } grid.arrange(grobs = plots, ncol = 2) } ``` ::: The we run the function by providing EducationLevel as the variable to examine. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} norm_test_wages(merged, 'educationLevel') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Take-Home_Ex1_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-24-1.png){width=1152} ::: ::: The results confirm that we can't assume Normality for the data points and we will proceed to apply a non-parametric test to check if the participants wages were different based on their education level. We use Median as the test statistic. For the nonparametric Kruskal-Willis Test, we hypothesize H0 = There is no difference between the median total wage of the participants with different education level at 0.05 level of significance. ::: {.cell fig.asp='0.618'} ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(123) ggbetweenstats( data = merged, x = educationLevel, y = total_wages, type = "np", pairwise_comparisons=TRUE, pairwise.display = "s", mean.plotting = FALSE, bf.message = FALSE, notch = TRUE, notchwidth = 0.1, ylab = "Total Wages", title = "One-Way ANOVA on Total Wages", messages = FALSE ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Take-Home_Ex1_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-25-1.png){width=1152} ::: ::: While the p-value of the Kruskal-Willis Test is \< 0.05 and the difference is total wages are significant, we cannot quantify how large this difference is. For this, we can then rely on the Partial Epsilon Squared value provided at the top of the chart, which indicates an Effect Size of 0.37. This means that the effect on education on total wage is large as can be seen that the median total wage of a Graduate (\$67k) is more than twice the amount of participants who received Low education (\$30k). This is further supported by the pairwise comparison of total wages between the education levels which shows significant difference in their wages. 5.3 Whether having children result in higher expenditure ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} norm_test_expenses <- function(df, column) { category <- if (is.factor(df[[column]])) { levels(df[[column]]) } else if (is.character(df[[column]])) { sort(unique(df[[column]])) } else { sort(unique(as.character(df[[column]]))) } plots <- list() for (class in category) { subset_df <- filter(df, !!sym(column) == class) shapiro_res <- shapiro.test(subset_df$total_expenses) p_value <- format(shapiro_res$p.value, digits = 3) is_normal <- ifelse(shapiro_res$p.value > 0.05, "Yes", "No") g <- ggplot(subset_df, aes(sample = total_expenses)) + stat_qq() + stat_qq_line() + ggtitle(paste('QQ Plot for', class)) + xlab(paste(column,':',class)) + ylab("Total Expenses") + theme_minimal() + annotate("label", x = -0.5, y = Inf, hjust = 1, vjust = 1.5, label = paste("Shapiro-Wilk Normality Test:", "\n", "p-value = ", p_value, "\n", "Is normal distn? ", is_normal), fill = "white" ) plots[[class]] <- g } grid.arrange(grobs = plots, ncol = 2) } ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} norm_test_expenses(merged,'haveKids') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Take-Home_Ex1_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){width=1152} ::: ::: We then conduct the 2-sample test ::: {.cell fig.asp='0.618'} ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(123) ggbetweenstats( data = merged, x = haveKids, y = total_expenses, type = "np", pairwise_comparisons=TRUE, pairwise.display = "s") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Take-Home_Ex1_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-28-1.png){width=1152} ::: ::: Breadkown of Expenses for participants who have kids ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} expenses_by_id_category <- financials_880 %>% filter(category != 'Wage') %>% group_by(participantId, category) %>% summarise(total_spent = sum(abs(amount))) %>% inner_join(select(survey, participantId, haveKids), by = "participantId") ``` ::: ::: {.cell fig.asp='0.618'} ```{.r .cell-code} p<- expenses_by_id_category %>% ggplot(aes(category, total_spent,fill=haveKids)) + stat_pointinterval( aes(interval_color = stat(fill)), position = position_dodge(), point_interval = median_qi, .width = 0.95, show.legend = TRUE ) + ylab("Total Spent") + xlab("Category") + theme_minimal() p + scale_fill_manual( values = c("#339900", "#FF9933"), labels = c("FALSE", "TRUE"), guide = guide_legend(title = "haveKids"), aesthetics = "interval_color") + #Title, subtitle, and caption labs(title = 'Visualising uncertainty in median estimates of resale price by town', subtitle = 'Quantiles intervals (95% and 99%) of resale price per flat area by Town, 2022', caption = 'Resale flat princes based on registration date from Jan-2017 onwards from data.gov.sg', x = "Planning Town", y = "Resale Price per sqm (SGD)") + theme_hc() + theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 18), plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14), legend.position = "top") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Take-Home_Ex1_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-30-1.png){width=1152} ::: ::: Based on the interval plot above, we see that all participants (with or without kids) have similar expenditures on the food and recreation. However, participants with no kid (orange interval lines) differ from participants with kid (blue interval lines) in 1. Participants with no kid do not have to incur education expenses 2. Participants with no kid spent lesser and faces lower uncertainties in terms of their expenditure to shelter. 5.3 Whether a higher education qualification results in more joy While those with higher education qualification receive more wages, does a better acamedic qualification translate to happiness? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} norm_test_joviality <- function(df, column) { category <- if (is.factor(df[[column]])) { levels(df[[column]]) } else if (is.character(df[[column]])) { sort(unique(df[[column]])) } else { sort(unique(as.character(df[[column]]))) } plots <- list() for (class in category) { subset_df <- filter(df, !!sym(column) == class) shapiro_res <- shapiro.test(subset_df$joviality) p_value <- format(shapiro_res$p.value, digits = 3) is_normal <- ifelse(shapiro_res$p.value > 0.05, "Yes", "No") g <- ggplot(subset_df, aes(sample = joviality)) + stat_qq() + stat_qq_line() + ggtitle(paste('QQ Plot for', class)) + xlab(paste(column,':',class)) + ylab("Joviality") + theme_minimal() + annotate("label", x = -0.5, y = Inf, hjust = 1, vjust = 1.5, label = paste("Shapiro-Wilk Normality Test:", "\n", "p-value = ", p_value, "\n", "Is normal distn? ", is_normal), fill = "white" ) plots[[class]] <- g } grid.arrange(grobs = plots, ncol = 2) } ``` ::: Let's test ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} norm_test_joviality(merged, 'educationLevel') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Take-Home_Ex1_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-32-1.png){width=1152} ::: ::: Again, it's a no and we will do the ANOVA test ::: {.cell fig.asp='0.618'} ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(123) ggbetweenstats( data = merged, x = educationLevel, y = joviality, type = "np", pairwise_comparisons=TRUE, pairwise.display = "s", bf.message = FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Take-Home_Ex1_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-33-1.png){width=1152} ::: ::: Although ANOVA test result show a p-value \< 0.005 indicating that there is a difference in joviality among participants with different education levels, this difference is attributed mainly to the statistically significant variance with between the joviality of participants who attended high school and graduate school. 5.4 Whether bigger households face a higher burden in the cost of living We modify normality test function to measure the effects of household size on the cost of living. For this purpose, we get a cost-to-wage percentage which is derived by dividing total expenses/total wages of each participant for the year. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} norm_test_cost <- function(df, column) { category <- if (is.factor(df[[column]])) { levels(df[[column]]) } else if (is.character(df[[column]])) { sort(unique(df[[column]])) } else { sort(unique(as.character(df[[column]]))) } plots <- list() for (class in category) { subset_df <- filter(df, !!sym(column) == class) shapiro_res <- shapiro.test(subset_df$expense_to_wage) p_value <- format(shapiro_res$p.value, digits = 3) is_normal <- ifelse(shapiro_res$p.value > 0.05, "Yes", "No") g <- ggplot(subset_df, aes(sample = expense_to_wage)) + stat_qq() + stat_qq_line() + ggtitle(paste('QQ Plot for', class)) + xlab(paste(column,':',class)) + ylab("Expense to Wage Ratio") + theme_minimal() + annotate("label", x = -0.5, y = Inf, hjust = 1, vjust = 1.5, label = paste("Shapiro-Wilk Normality Test:", "\n", "p-value = ", p_value, "\n", "Is normal distn? ", is_normal), fill = "white" ) plots[[class]] <- g } grid.arrange(grobs = plots, ncol = 2) } ``` ::: let's test ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} norm_test_cost(merged, "householdSize") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Take-Home_Ex1_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-35-1.png){width=1152} ::: ::: Again, we will apply non-parametric test to compare the difference ::: {.cell fig.asp='0.618'} ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(123) ggbetweenstats( data = merged, x = householdSize, y = expense_to_wage, type = "np", pairwise_comparisons=TRUE, pairwise.display = "s", bf.message = FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Take-Home_Ex1_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-36-1.png){width=1152} ::: ::: The p-value is \> 0.05 indicating that there is insufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis that the cost_to_wage ratio for larger households are different or higher. Hence, we can also infer that even though we notice families with kid incur higher expenses in Section 5.2, generally, these residents of bigger households will earn more to defray the higher cost of living. conclusion Reference - How to conduc and visualise Kruskal-Wallis Test [(6) R demo \| Kruskal-Wallis test + Post-Hoc \| How to conduct, visualize, interpret & more ðŸ˜‰ - YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U-hS2zoRPOY) [Two-Sample t-Test \| Introduction to Statistics \| JMP](https://www.jmp.com/en_sg/statistics-knowledge-portal/t-test/two-sample-t-test.html) [One Way ANOVA (gribblelab.org)](https://gribblelab.org/teaching/stats2019/notes/One_Way_ANOVA.pdf)
